description: Kiwis, also known as kiwifruits or Chinese gooseberries, are small, oval-shaped fruits with brown fuzzy skin and vibrant green or yellow flesh. They are native to China but are now cultivated in many regions with temperate climates, including New Zealand, Italy, and California. Kiwis are known for their unique sweet-tart flavor and are rich in vitamin C, vitamin K, and dietary fiber. They are typically eaten fresh, sliced, or added to fruit salads, smoothies, and desserts. Kiwi vines are vigorous climbers that require sturdy support structures to grow properly.
varieties: Kiwis, also known as kiwifruits or Chinese gooseberries, come in various cultivars, each with its unique flavor, texture, and appearance. Some popular kiwi varieties include 'Hayward', prized for its large size, fuzzy brown skin, and vibrant green flesh with black seeds; 'Zespri Gold', known for its golden skin and sweet, tropical flavor; 'Issai', favored for its small size, smooth skin, and self-fertile nature; and 'Jenny', valued for its early ripening and excellent flavor. These varieties, among others, offer a range of options suited for different climates and taste preferences.

sowingAndPlanting.sowingIndoorsDescription: Kiwis are typically propagated from seeds or cuttings. To grow from seeds, rinse kiwi seeds to remove any fruit flesh and dry them thoroughly. Plant seeds in pots filled with well-draining potting mix and keep them warm and moist. Germination may take several weeks.
sowingAndPlanting.sowingOutdoorsDescription: Kiwis can also be propagated by cuttings. Take 6-8 inch cuttings from healthy kiwi vines in late winter or early spring. Remove the lower leaves and dip the cut end in rooting hormone. Plant cuttings in pots filled with well-draining potting mix and keep them warm and moist until roots develop.
sowingAndPlanting.season: Kiwis should be planted in late winter or early spring while they are still dormant. They prefer well-drained soil and are hardy to USDA zones 7-9.

careAndMaintenance.growingDescription: Kiwis prefer full sun to partial shade and well-draining soil rich in organic matter. They require regular watering, especially during dry periods, to keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. Mulch around plants to conserve moisture, suppress weeds, and maintain even soil temperature.
careAndMaintenance.wateringNeeds: Regular watering, aiming for 1-2 inches per week.
careAndMaintenance.soilFertility: Incorporate compost or well-aged manure into the soil before planting to improve fertility and soil structure. Fertilize kiwis annually with a balanced fertilizer according to package instructions.
careAndMaintenance.pruningRequirements: Prune kiwi vines in late winter or early spring to remove dead, diseased, or overcrowded growth. Train vines onto a trellis or support structure and prune to maintain shape and encourage fruit production.
careAndMaintenance.supportRequirements: Kiwis require support as they grow. Train vines onto a sturdy trellis or support structure and tie them in place as they grow. Prune vines to keep them manageable and prevent overcrowding.

harvestingAndStorage.timeToMaturity: Kiwis typically begin producing fruit 3-5 years after planting, depending on the variety and growing conditions.
harvestingAndStorage.storageRecommendations: Harvest kiwis when they are fully ripe, usually in late summer or early fall. Kiwis are ripe when they yield to gentle pressure and have a slight give. Store harvested kiwis at room temperature for up to one week, or refrigerate them for longer storage.
harvestingAndStorage.harvestDescription: Harvest kiwis when they have reached their full size and have a slightly soft texture. Use a sharp knife to cut the fruit from the vine, leaving a short stem attached.

goodCompanionPlants.name: Comfrey
goodCompanionPlants.description: Comfrey is a dynamic accumulator, bringing up nutrients from deep in the soil and making them available to kiwi plants. Its deep roots also help improve soil structure and prevent erosion.

goodCompanionPlants.name: Clover
goodCompanionPlants.description: Clover is a nitrogen-fixing plant that can enrich the soil with nitrogen, benefiting kiwi plants. It also acts as a ground cover, suppressing weeds and reducing soil erosion.

goodCompanionPlants.name: Borage
goodCompanionPlants.description: Borage attracts pollinators like bees, which are essential for kiwi fruit production. It also improves soil health and helps deter pests like aphids with its strong scent.

goodCompanionPlants.name: Lavender
goodCompanionPlants.description: Lavender has aromatic foliage that can help repel pests like mosquitoes and flies from the kiwi garden. It also attracts pollinators like bees and butterflies, enhancing fruit set.

goodCompanionPlants.name: Chives
goodCompanionPlants.description: Chives can deter pests like aphids and Japanese beetles with their strong scent when planted near kiwi plants. They are also edible and can be harvested for culinary use.

badCompanionPlants.name: Grass
badCompanionPlants.description: Grass and other ground covers that compete with kiwi plants for nutrients, water, and sunlight should be avoided. They can also provide habitat for pests and diseases that affect kiwi plants.

badCompanionPlants.name: Walnuts
badCompanionPlants.description: Walnut trees produce juglone, a chemical compound that inhibits the growth of many plants, including kiwi vines. Avoid planting kiwi vines near walnut trees.

badCompanionPlants.name: Sunflower
badCompanionPlants.description: Sunflowers can compete with kiwi vines for sunlight, water, and nutrients, potentially reducing fruit production. Additionally, sunflowers may attract birds that can damage kiwi crops.

badCompanionPlants.name: Tomatoes
badCompanionPlants.description: Tomatoes have different soil and water requirements than kiwi plants and may compete for resources. Additionally, tomatoes may attract pests and diseases that can affect kiwi vines.

badCompanionPlants.name: Rhubarb
badCompanionPlants.description: Rhubarb is not recommended to be planted near kiwi vines, as it may compete for nutrients and water. Additionally, rhubarb leaves contain oxalic acid, which can be harmful to kiwi plants.

tipsAndTricks: Plant kiwi vines in well-drained soil with full sun exposure.
Provide sturdy support structures such as trellises or pergolas for kiwi vines to climb.
Water kiwi vines regularly, especially during dry periods.
Apply a balanced fertilizer during the growing season to promote healthy growth.
Prune kiwi vines in late winter to remove old wood and promote fruiting spurs.
Monitor vines regularly for signs of pests and diseases, and take appropriate action.
Harvest kiwis when they are fully ripe but still firm to the touch.
Store harvested kiwis in the refrigerator for extended freshness.
